H0.text: Metals are typically described by the characteristics listed: usually solid at room temperature, can be bent or changed in shape without breaking, and show a shiny luster when scratched or polished.

H1.text: Nonmetals are typically described by the characteristics listed: usually solid at room temperature, can be bent or changed in shape without breaking, and show a shiny luster when scratched or polished.

H2.text: Elements are the group typically described by the characteristics: they are usually solid at room temperature, can be bent or changed in shape without breaking, and show a shiny luster when scratched or polished.

H3.text: Compounds are typically described by the characteristics listed below: usually solid at room temperature, can be bent or changed in shape without breaking, and show a shiny luster when scratched or polished.

A4.text: Metals are typically ductile (can be drawn into a wire) and malleable (can be shaped via hammering or pressing).

A5.text: A metal (from Ancient Greek μέταλλον (métallon) 'mine, quarry, metal') is a material that, when polished or fractured, shows a lustrous appearance
